Post-goût long, légèrement amer dalcool doux à la fois liquoreux et vineux avec un goût fruité sucré et aux notes sûres (framboises) ainsi que des notes chocolatées.
Bottle.  Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, caramel, raspberry. Flavour is alcohol, malt, caramel, raspberry, chocolate, hop, dried fruits. Full body. Nice beer.

Bottle 187ml. [2007]
Pours red with brownish reflects. No head. Aroma is of malt, sweet, fruits, raspberries, cherries. Taste is of sweet, malt, fruits, raspberries, alcohol, sligth acidity. Some tartness. Palate: full bodied, sticky texture. Overall: Very nice beer, intense fruit features. Still malty enough, almost bready. Good balance.

This rating is for a bottle from the 2007 bottling. Nice little bottle, it opens up with a little "pschitt". Pours clear red with no head to speak of. Aroma is full of chocolate and raspberries. The beer itself has little to no carbonation but that doesnt get in the way of our tasting. A little sour, it tastes like a nice chocolate/raspberry cake. It goes down really smooth and begs for another sip. I deeply believe that I could have drunk multiple bottles of this (one sip at a time of course), good thing it is packaged in such a small bottle. Lovely!

Nip bottle, 2007 vintage. Shared by Mathieuc, huge thanks! Brown with reddish reflects, no head, no lacing. Aroma is of intense chocolate and raspberries. Taste is sweet, intensely chocolate and strong raspberries notes. Slight acidic presence from the raspberries that help to balance the beer. Sirupy. Warming alcohol. I was surprised by the strong chocolate presence. The bottom of the bottle was tasting raspberries jam. Nice sipper!

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 bottle 2007. pours ruby red minimal head. big port and berry aroma. taste is very sweet and sticky like a nice glass of ice wine

re rate 2/16/2013. on draft almost same beer but a lot more heat from the booze and less sweet raspberry

6 oz bottle vintage from 2007, Pours very viscous dark red burgundy color with no head what so ever. The body of the beer clings to the side of the glass like oil. Nose is something unfamiliar to me, hints of horse blanket, oxidation, and big push of quality chocolate and slight hints of dried fruits. The flavor on this one is where it shines, pure raspberry and chocolate, the density of flavor that is reached here is truly unique. Seems to stil have some acidic kick and a bit of bitterness. Intense chocolate and raspberry sweetness, each sip surpassing the last. The beer drinks like a port, viscous and long lingering. Truly impressed by the uniqueness and the quality of flavor.

Bottle, 6.3oz, shared by fonefan. 2004 vintage. Its a lightly unclear one, brown in color and with some rapidly diminishing beige bubbles on top. Lightly oxidized aroma with caramel and toffee, dried fruits, hints of raspberry and some alcohol. The flavor has more raspberry than the aroma, in a very pleasant way. Caramel, dried fruits, oxidation and a little bitterness too. Full body, warming and with some tart-ish notes, even though its quite sweet. A tasteful beer indeed, but its hard to tell whether its the age that prevents me from going wild (the beers age, not mine) or if its because the beer world has evolved quite a bit since 2004. Still, a wonderful beer it is. 121109

Bottle, 2004 @ FOneFan courtesy FOneFan. Deep red/brown with no head. Aroma is malt, raspberries, dark fruits and a little oxidized. Flavour is malt, raspberry, little sweet, little oxidized, little sweet,

Bottle 250ml vintage 2004 @ fonefan
Pours clear reddish brown with no head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, chocolate and raspberries. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter with a long fruity, caramel finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.
Botte @ fonefan tasting. Vintage 2004. Clear deep red with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, chocolate and raspberry. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. 091112

Bottle from 2004 @ fonefan tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are rich raspberries, caramel, fruits, malt, alcohol, chocolate, wood and hops. Nice and creamy.

Bottle from 06 thanks to BBB63. Pours a nices ruby red with a pinkish head. The nose and taste are as expected even with 5+ years of age- big raspberry, a bit of oxidation (Which is a nice thing on this beer) a touch of caramel, very enjoyable.

A - pours hazy dark brown with amber edges. No head, some lacing. S - strong aromas of raspberry jam, grains, heavy toffee, dates, dark honey, dark fruits, caramel, caramelized sugars, brown sugar, and molasses. M - heavy bodied full rich palate. Nice well balanced. Sour, then rich tangy full malty good. T - tart  raspberry liquor and raspberry jam up front. Moves to a rich caramel, molasses, dark honey, dates, oak tannins, cocoa powder. Lingering leather, oak tannins, vinous and caramel malts and solid alcohol warming. O - amazing rich and rounded strong rich full bodied fruit beer.  4.2

It took a road trip from Detroit to Chicago with stops all the way to get this beer, some years ago.     I was treasured with this beer.    Its caramelly, fruityness, and smooth finish was astounding.     Worthy of the aclaim.

Been saving a bottle, perhaps to drink the rain away on this chilly New England morning. Bottle, 2007 edition. Pours an amazingly gelatinous  blood-red, zero carbonation, absolutely nothing to speak of. Smells of booze. Aged caramel. Champaign yeast. Raspberries. Wood rosin. Earth. After tasting it, however, I have to say its a lot like chewing on a raspberry-flavored Chapstik: its dry, viscous, too sweet and very chemical. There was some nuttiness, earth, caramel and chocolate by-mid-palate to swallow, but just the fact I couldnt finish this beer alone says a lot to me.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2013 Bottle to snifter (HUGE thanks to tmoney99). Looks solid; a deep caramel amber color that is still. Smells good; chocolate, caramel, and raspberries. Tastes like it smells, but has evolved into a liquor. Nice on the palate too. Excellent!

Update: the new 2012 vintage is similar, but better in appearance (not still), and delightfully raspberry-forward.

18cl, Vintage 2007, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, with raspberries, thx alot to Secret Santa!, very complex fruit brew, fruity/alcoholic and slightly sour/sweet, not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, top class Winter brew!, yet very expensive!, WOW!

Little 2007 nip bottle shared by Gillard, thanks Ryan, poured a deep red color, aromas of dry raspberries, wood, light choclate, and some caramel.  Flavors are the same with rasppberries and booze dominating  the flavors.  Real nice beer overall woould love to try more of it.

2007 bottle at home to celebrate hitting 2K. It pours cloudy deep mahogany, with no head whatsoever. The nose is indulgent, rich chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, raspberry jam, wood, vanilla, earthiness and booze. The taste is fresh raspberry, dark fruit, touch of fruit tartness, jammy, underlying alcohol warmth, bitter chocolate, wood, leather and vinous notes, with a dry, warming finish. Full body and low carbonation. Super smooth and excellently balanced. Great complexity and flavour, a unique beer experience!

Serving: 187 ml. bottle from CheeseMan.  Thanks big time Daniel!  It pours a muddy, reddish brown with no head.  Seems rather viscous and the small bubbles of carbonation cant escape this swirling brew.  The nose has a bit of dark chocolate, raspberry liqueur, dates, dried cherries, and very dark caramel.  The flavor has bold, tart raspberry and cherry notes, leather, and cocoa powder.   The sweetness up front is replaced with a dry tartness on the back end. Very rich and full bodied with a lasting finish.  This one definitely expanded my thoughts about what beer can do.  Pretty damn outstanding.

187 ml bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. 2007 vintage. Pours hazy reddish brown, rather madeira-like, with no worth mentioning. Smell is intense, sweet and tiny fruity with caramel, cocoa powder, raspberries, wood, alcohol, burnt sugar, moist tobacco, wood, nougat, leather, vanilla fudge, caramel heavy toffee, brazil nuts, very dark honey and some hints of earthy oxidation. Taste is massive, sweet, tiny bitter and very tiny sour with loads of caramel, quality dark chocolate, raspberries, dark honey, burning alcohol, vanilla fudge, brazil nut toffee, sweet dark bread, dry wood, earthy tobacco and hints of leather, milk chocolate and hints of dusty oxidation. Mouthfeel is round, vinous, boozy and full bodied with no carbonation to speak of. Finish is sweet with caramel, milk chocolate, slightly overripe raspberries, honey and hints of roasted candy-coated nuts. Very intense desert beer.

June 29, 2012 bottle shared by Brandon.  Pour looked like a really strong iced tea.  Aroma was alcohol, caramel, chocolate and some raspberry.  Taste was consistent with aroma, kind of like a chocolate covered raspberry.  Very smooth and medium bodied.  Bottle was 2004 vintage.  Thanks Brandon, I have been looking to try this for a long time!

Has some really nice chocolate aromas which mask the cherry quite a bit. Taste is strong chocolate with sweet raspberry, light booze taste but finishes well.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2004 & 2007 vintages side by side. Thanks Brad!

A: virtually flat and almost no lace. I must take into account the age and the style.

S: Chocolate, cherries (though Im sure it must be raspberries Im actually smelling), alcohol

T: Chocolate. I must admit, I wasnt expecting that. The chocolate was more pronounced in the 2004. There was little raspberry to speak of. Chocolate and alcohol dominate the majority of the taste profile.

M: smooth as is possible, given the huge ABV.

D: Great for sipping. A few ounces as a nightcap was a treat.

Notes: Ill seek this out again. Recommended.

Bottle 18,7 cl tnx to Greg. Pours deep dark red brown with a minimal red-taned  head. Aroma is fantastic; caramel raspberries sweet malty toasted prunes raisins alcohol fruity. Flavor is very rich; vinous, a bit acidy sour, fruity, raspberries in the start. More intense raspberries with warming alcohol and toastiness and slight caramel tones and some bitterness. Raspberries and the warming alcohol feeling stay all the way to the end with nice bitter touch. Finishes with a pleasant longlived raspberry fruity and a bit bitter aftertaste. Very nice as a desert or as for me after a long days work starting my vacation.

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. After drain-pouring the last two, Ive decided to drink something awesome instead! Pours muddy purple/brown, no head, no lacing, and Im guessing no carbonation... Nose is big raspberry, Tootsie Roll, chocolate, fig, cassis, a bit of leather. Flavours of tart raspberries, light fruit acid, leather, toffee, tart and nippy. Virtually no carbonation... Nice, but considering the hype, maybe I dont get it?

Bottle (2004):  Dark brown with deep red highlights. Very hazy. Very small head that fades quick and leaves hardly any lace. But I wasnt expecting much with 13.5%ABV.  Outstanding Eisbock. Chocolate covered raspberries overwelm my mouth with my first sip. An amazing beer! Not a whole lot to say except if you get a chance to try it dont pass it up.

2007 Bottle. Pours a murked out purp. Aromas of mary jane, mollases, dark raspberry, honey mead. Taste is chocolate, raspberrys, sugary caramel, toffee, fresh baked pie. Layered with flavors. Easy drinking for the percentage. Awesome.

This 2007 vintage is courtesy of weirdbeer, thank you immensely Joe! This one puts a medium bodied and syrupy amber to red in color. The aromas are like concentrated Raspberry jam. It smells delicious! Its also very malty. It tastes of sweet and tart raspberry jam. Oh my god its delicious and ultimately spectacular. What a masterpiece! This beer is almost unfathomable. It is hands down one of the best beers Ive ever had, and that means a lot.

2004 bottle with pat and James. Pours a very dark yet clear brown with no head. Smell is faint but some raspberry notes. Taste is a nice mix of chocolate and raspberry jam. Faintly reminds me of a sort of malt chocolate. A real treat.

Big thanks FlandersNed.  Huge want of mine.  2007 Bottle.  Brown with red and yellow hues, light bubbles coming up to the surface.  Aroma of meaty raspberry and dark fruit.  Flavor starts light caramel, bitter raspberry.  Middle is layered tart raspberry and refined caramel candy/toasted malt.  Finishes dry, sour raspberry with toasted and light roasted malt/chocolate.  Alcohol is present in the middle and finish, but not detracting.  Very layered.

From notes.  First reviewed 8/19/2011.  Poured from a 6.3 oz. bottle into a tulip. 2007 vintage. Thanks to readbaron for sharing this.

This has a medium brown color with a raspberry tint. Slightly transparent edges. No head, this is pretty flat, just a few stray bubbles.

There is a definite blast of raspberries in the nose. This is so much better than what I had heard from other people at this point. For a 2007, this smells like raspberries just picked off the bush. Some malt sweetness behind the tart raspberry aroma.

The flavor is full of raspberriess, both sweet and sour and everywhere in between. Some toffee and malt flavors give it a kick of sweetness and a little bit more depth, but the focus is on the raspberries. Just fantastic.

The bottle is pretty much flat, and the body is fuller than medium. A light tart acidity is there, as is a light booziness.

Wow, this beer impresses. Unfortunately the bottles are so tiny and they have not made it in four years, so finding more seems to be pretty difficult.

bottle through recent trade 2007 bottle opened with a slight hiss. pour has a earthy amber color and basically no head and a still look. aroma has raspberry seeds, odd chocolate, jam sweetness, and toffee. certainly a strange concoction and centered around the raspberry. mouth feel is medium full with a big coating sweetness and basically no carbonation. flavor is rich, berry centered, again the chocolate hits, and caramel. this is like drinking an aged berry tart. there are some burnt toffee flavors that come through as it opens up and this is quite desert like.
Nip bottle thanks to deyholla. Huge raspberry syrup flavor.  seedy jam, caramel, and toffee.  Really nice raspberry, a sipper for sure.  Thick mouthfeel.  I am very glad to try this beer finally.
Definately an after dinner sipper...a rich raspberry chocolate alchemy of candy/beer.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Bloomington, Indiana, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 Kuhnhenn Raspberry Eisbock pours a deep red violet appearance with little to no head. Rich raspberry syrupy, caramel, toffee, mild chocolate aroma. Rich, somewhat tart, raspberry fruity, caramel, toffee flavor. Honestly, this has a lot of flavor going on but it has burnt, tar-like taste that I dont particularly care for. This was poured from a 2007 nip bottle. Update: 2012 12.7 oz bottle is pretty chill but still a bit oxidized. Booze is hidden pretty well.

2007 nip bottle pour into glass is dark reddish brown with thin to almost no off white head.  Aroma is raspberries, and more raspberries, into some slight caramel and hints of cocoa, even get some of the tart and earth from the raspberries in there as well.  Taste is like sipping a delicious raspberry dessert, some big raspberries like the aroma but much more caramel, toffee, and cocoa in there with a hint of earth, finishing fairly sweet with a nice tart note, no alcohol in there at all.  Awesome stuff.
Raspberries, caramel, and chocolate aromas and flavors make this an amazing fruit beer. Sweet, strong and amazing!

2007 nipper bottle.  Pours a flat murky red/brown.  Very silky smooth and very low carbonation if anything.  Aroma is raspberries very strong with vanilla and a unique nuttyness.  Taste is caramel, cherry, raspberry, and a vanilla sweetness.  Very unique stuff and quite good.  I wished for some carbonation to make the flavor a little more lively but still good.
Courtesy of reynolds314. Big sweet flavors, some cherry type flavors over raspberry type flavors. Im really liking this.

Bottled. Deep ruby red colour with a small pinkish head. Aroma is raspberries, spices, some mild alcohol, nutty notes as well as some slight chocolaty (?!?) notes. Flavour is raspberries, mild spices, some sweet alcohol as well as some mild tartness as well. Beautifully balanced.

2007 vintage. 

Pours a very dark ruby red color thats almost brown with plum colored edges and a thin beige ring that slowly fades. Not much in the way of lacing. 

Sweet, slightly boozy aroma that surprisingly is still fruit forward after four years. Lots of sweet dark raspberry and other dark fruits along with some dark chocolate cake, caramel and toffee. Subtle medicinal/syrup quality. 

Fuller bodied than expected with some soft carbonation and a really nice balance of sweet, syrupy fruit, silky dark malts and subtle boozy heat/sweetness. Similarly to the aroma, there is still a surprising amount of juicy raspberry and other dark fruit notes. Faint tartness with some cranberry before being countered by hits of chocolate cake, caramel and toffee. Slightly syrupy but this doesnt hurt the mouthfeel much. A nice boozy warmth in the finish but the high ABV is excellently masked with only little heat. This beer is dangerously drinkable at this stage so 6.3oz is a perfect serving. Complex with a good amount of raspberry still in there. The perfect drink for after a huge holiday meal.

2007 Bottle pour from Armin.  Big,  big thanks.  Pour is a hazy red brown, with just a whisp of a head and no lacing.  Aroma is huge raspberry seeds, some caramel, a touch of biscuit.  Taste is vodka soaked raspberries, in the best possible way.  Sugary sweet finish, I would love to know what the FG on this is.  Fantastic desert beer, though very one D.

Bottle. Pours red-brown. No head. Intense and beautiful aroma with notes of chocolate, cacao, red berries and something slightly salty. VERY fruity. Tastes choclate and sour raspberries. Small tartness.

Bottle.
Pours red brown without any head.
Intens fruity aroma of bananas, raspberries, raspberry seeds, mango and chcolate.
Tastes fruity of rapsberries and blood oranges. Smooth.
2007 poured a red colour with not much head. The raspberry was prominent on the nose and the taste too, could def taste the alcohol, very nice Eisbock.

Tiny lil bottle enjoyed with the mikes. Cloudy hazy red brown with no head at all. Nose is sharp alcohol and medicinal bite with fruitiness. Mouth is huge! So much more flavor and movement than expected. Hints of creaminess before the flavor even registers on the tastebuds because the creaminess disappears when the tart and spiciness hits. Bitter chocolate hints and an interesting warming character. Tons of movement and complexity. I need a few more of these.

11.7 oz bottle curtesy of Boutip (Phil) from 2007. Dark mahogany with no head.  Dark chocolate and raspberry, booze, plum, toffee, vanilla. Decent carbonation (surprisingly), medium mouthfeel, smooth, sweet with some cough syrup and spice, nice long lasting finish with cherry more then raspberry at first, then more of the latter. Unfortunately the finish and taste dont live up to the aroma...still tasty and worth trying though.

2007 bottle from a great BA trader. Reddish brown with barely a head from a tall pour that fades to a tiny ring. Aroma is big fresh raspberry up front with some bread dough, vanilla, alcohol and faint cocoa. The flavor is lots of acidic raspberry that really bites the palate, some bitter chocolate and an alcohol warming. Medium body with mild carbonation and a dry, chalky mouth feel. Smells great but the acidity of this is overboard. Looking at the reviews, maybe the 2007 batch was off because this isnt a great beer. Ive had this once before and that bottle was a bit better but not sure of the vintage.

bottle thanks to jrallen34.  poured reddish brown with a tiny off-white/beige head.  aroma was simply fantastic with raspberry, fudge, a little leather, and some dark sweet chocolate.  flavor was everything that I hoped it would be with fudge, caramel, raspberry, and slight tartness.  body was creamy and silky.  This was an absolute delight to drink.

Big thanks to FooFaa for bringing this one to Ffej of July IX. If I had to guess I think it was an 07

A - Pours brownish red with a small half finger tall white head leaving spotty lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of chocolate covered raspberries with a few helping hints of toffee, vanilla, oak, and some warm booze. This one has a lot going on.

T - Starts off with an intense raspberry puree flavor quickly giving way to a mix of sweet chocolate, vanilla, dry oak tannins, and some warming booze. It is quite sweet but the other flavors help to keep in check as much as they can. The finish is a mix of sweetness and light booze, lingering for some time.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Slick, smooth, feel with a good amount of booze still present.

O - This one is definitely a sipper but it is a very good one. It has so much flavor going on. It is a perfect desert beer, but that is truly its only fault, I doubt this would taste as good as it does paired with a big juicy steak. Glad I finally got to try it again.

Tiny 2007 Bottle. Went to wrap for a trade and the cap popped. Oh well. Time to drink and rate it instead. Aroma of  dark cherries and raspberries. Poured a cloudy reddish-brown with no carbonation or head. Flavor is sweet, with an impressive amount of ripe cherry and caramel notes. Wish I had chilled this down more, as it warmed quick, but still refreshing. Thick and rich, with a smooth mouthfeel. Long notes of tart cherries and sweet raspberries on the finish. Slightly dry aftertaste. Would be great as a tasty dessert (with ice cream). Will have to find another =)

(bottle courtesy of alexsdad06! 2007 vintage)  Ive had this in the cellar for at least 6 months now and my 1000th rating seemed to be the perfect time to open it up.  Pours into a rochefort chalice.  Pours cloudy dark brown-red color with no real head.  Smells like a raspberry truffle with a bit of alcohol.  Mmmmm.  Taste is sweet and tart.  The raspberry is quite tart with sweetness also coming from the fruit and seemingly from chocolate and caramel.  Full bodied with a slick texture.  Finish is very smooth and has some noticeable alcohol, but its not distracting.  This is a very unique beer and Im very happy to have tried this.  Many, many thanks Brad!

Bottle (2007 vintage)...  Poured deep, ruby/burgundy and a thin head.  Nose had raspberries and a brandy-like booze tone.  Low heat, it really brined off nicely. Raspberries, hard candy, a slight cardboard/oxidized character.  Thick, syrupy, strong sweetness.

A 2007 bottle from jrallen34. Thanks a lot guy!! Pours reddish brown with no head. Aroma is something like raspberry over dark caramel, but its aged raspberry. Flavor is somewhat medicinal raspberry with dark/chocolate caramel. Had a hint from the description, but thats about right. With repeated sipping the raspberry freshens and the chocolate firms. There  is some mellow aging in this, and it just keeps getting better and better.

Tiny bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a brownish red, faint tan head. Aroma had a bit of leather, funk, raspberry, dark fruit, licorice, pepper, subtle spice. Flavor is much the same. Mouthfeel is medium body, low to no carbonation. Overall, was a very nice treat!!!!

Tief malziger Geruch, deutlich alkoholisch und karamellig. Fruchtig-karameliger Antrunk und Mittelteil, der trotz der über 10% sehr harmonisch wirkt. Weiter sehr süffig und malzig, negativ fällt nur der trockene Abgang auf. Fruchtige Noten sind in weiten Teilen des Biers erkennbar, mit der Zeit wird es süßer und malziger. 	 
Test vom 27.6.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,12,11,12,5,12 - 11,20

By far one of the most amazing beers I have ever sampled in my entire life.  Thanks to Skyhand for sampling me one of these back in the day.  Its been a while now, but I literally remember this smelling like the biggest and baddest dish of chocolate raspberry filled ice cream Id ever come across in my life.  The flavors continued from the nose, bringing out caramel, wood, cherries, fudge, and straight up EPICSAUCE.  Ive still almost 4 or 5 years later not tasted anything else like it.  Pretty sure this was a 4 year old bottle, aged, perfectly.  Hope to definitely try this again someday!

Tap at Rattle for the Kuhnhenn takeover. Poured dark brown/ruby with a very thin head. Really nice raspberry aroma along with some caramel, wood, toast, chocolate. Huge raspberry flavor with a light tartness but also a malty sweetness that balances out very nicely. More chocolate on the palate. Flavorful, complex, quite delicious.
Bottle shared by beernbourbon. Pours cloudy red. aroma is all raspberry with hints of booze. taste is similar to the aroma, but has hints of caramel. Overall an excellent beer.

2007 bottle, drinking in 4/2011.

Looks like maple syrup.  Very little head but some remains on the edges throughout.

Super malty, boozy smell, like a barleywine thats turned over but hasnt gone bad.

Ah, beautiful taste.  Like chocolate covered raspberries.  Very tart finish.  Toffee malts in there too.  A great swirl of flavors.  Right combination of sweet and tart and well-blended too.  Oak and cherry flavors too.  The booze is definitely present, but the booze is needed to put an edge on the sweetness/tartness.
Draft @ rnh. Pours a deep darl purple coilor. No head. Smells of malyt, fruit and syrup. Ytasye is similar with some grapes and raisins. Could be a sour or a begian strong. Over all. Really good

On draft at RattleNHum... The aroma is as expected with sweet, tart raspberries and mild chocolate.  Its difficult to detect much else.  The appearance is a strange muddled brick brown with a very thin ring of carbonation laying around the surface.  On the palate, as it warms the body richens up and the beer becomes quite decadent and creamy.  The flavor develops as well, evolving into a tart, mildly acidic raspberry flavor with a mousse-like dark chocolate on the finish.  The flavor lingers for minutes after drinking and coats the palate.  8oz is well large enough for a serving, but wow... really good and a lot of fun.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2014 Draft at RnH with Andrew, Streets, and Brendan during the Kuhnhenn Brewery Tap Takeover Event. Listed as Vintage 2007. Pours a deep, murky muddy brown body with no head and just the finest carbonated lacing. Aroma is full of pomegranate and raspberries dipped in chocolate.  Mouthfeel is slightly carbonated, full bodied with notes of chocolate covered cherries, oak, sweet fudge, and other dark fruits. Definitely lives up to the hype and expectations.
Beautiful aroma that gives a hint to its fruitiness. The tast is like chocolate covered raspberries and cherries. Best fruit beer I have ever had
On tap at RnH.  Brown with reddish tint.  Vanilla, prune, pom aroma. Dark fruit tang... Prunes, pomegranate, blackberry:rasp.  Unreal for nearly 12%. Subtle tabacco notes as well.  World class.

I split the 2007 bottle into two snifter to share with a friend. I also gave a small sip to a non beer geek. We were blessed with a slight brown fizz (I stole that word).That fizz didnt last long but I expected that. The body was a murky black so the appearance really wasnt much to look at.. Now were this brew starts to shine is the aroma chocolate raspberry tart was the first word I hear to describe it, and it stuck in my head. The flavor was more of the same it had great chocolate caramel and a ton of raspberries in it. This was a desert in a glass and the mouth feel was thick and syrupy so it was a perfect aperitif. All around this was a great brew.

Serving type: bottle

Tiny ass bottle acquired via trade and consumed after a meal in very tiny portions with my friend Brian. Murky reddish brown pour with a small tan head that lingered throughout most of the drink. (Though thats not difficult with such a small portion!) Raspberry smacks you in the face when you take a whiff of this one, but theres a nearly as prominent chocolate aroma as well as some caramel in there lurking behind those two. The taste is very juicy raspberries with a nice backing of chocolate and caramel, very satisfying on the lips. This is easily one of the best fruit beers Ive ever had, and its a shame its so expensive for such a small bottle.

Tap (notes from 09). Deep rich ruby red color, with no head at all.  Rich dark ripe fruit, definitely the raspberries in the depth, touch sweet as well.  Sweet candied raspberries, fruity, and not really getting any of the chocolate.  Almost a bit cloying with some sweetness, but stops short of annoying.

Rating # 600. Bottle. Pours clear dark red/brown with a tiny offwhite head. Aroma is alcohol, raspberries, dried fruit, raisins, chocolate notes. Flavor is sour raspberries, bitter chocolate, dark fruit, sweet cake (?). Complex, well balanced. Oily texture, nice lacings. Great.

Had both the 2004 and 2007 vintages at a recent tasting. Thanks everyone, this was a long time curiosity for me. I feel as thought I had built it up in my mind a bit too much and was slightly let down. Eisbocks (bocks in general) are one of the styles I study a lot. This was an interesting example.

2004 - Beer was brown and clear with no carbonation, no head, no lacing. The aroma was strong full of malt and caramel. Definitely smell the raspberries and some chocolate? Wasnt expecting the chocolate smell. Lots of sweetness up front, raspberries come in late in the palate and are generally weak. Mostly a tart flavor from the raspberries. There is a lot of chocolate flavors in the midpalate regions. I find this flavor to be distracting and unnecessary. I find myself wishing that it was the malt and the berries without the chocolate. I know that the chocolate and the raspberry flavors pair well with food, but to stand the tart raspberry flavor next to the malt sweetness would have been great in my opinion.

2007 - Looks the same as the 2004, no head, no carbonation. The aroma is considerably stronger. Much more raspberries and the chocolate is still there. The flavor pops with a lot more raspberries. This is definitely my favorite out of the two. The sweetness from the malt is still there, the chocolate is less the star in this one. This beer is also thicker (it seems) than the 2004.

Overall, Im glad I got to try them both. Im not sure if I would seek it out again though.

Serving type: bottle

Pours very dark amber almost brown, very light brown head, no lacing, clear and oily looking.

The aroma is very strong like a chocolate covered raspberry straight from a chocolatier. There are also notes of carmel and a touch of alcohol.

Taste is excellent and strong and sticks to your mouth. Almost like youre eating a piece of candy. You cant chug this but sip it and you will get tons of flavors like chocolate, raspberry, vanilla, and a touch of alcohol. The ending is all vanilla a nice surprise. 

Mouthfeel is superb, chunky and sticky.

2004 batch drank 12/5/10

A-pours a dark copper color, almost muddy brown with a thin tan colored head.

S-this has a huge malt component to it, notes of alcohol and heat.  there is tons of dark milk chocolate and toffee notes in this, notes of fusel alcohol and maple in the nose.  chocolate cake and maple syrup towards the finish.

T-this again is extremely malt, somewhat sweet and a little boozy in the back.  chocoalte cake, cookie, sweet sticky toffee, notes of maple syrup, some thinner flavors in the back and slightly minerally in the finish.

M-this is heavy and chewy, thick and syrupy, the feel is velvety and the carbonation is low but holds.  the finish is robust in feel and sticky on the back of the throat.

D-this has a huge malt component to it and the fruits are almost non existent.  the malts are sweet and the back adds very cake/fudge like flavors.  interesting malt body, nose is pretty solid, flavor gets a little minerally and bitter in the finish.

******************************

2007 batch drank early 2010

A-dark copper in color with deep reddish colored edges.  The head is thin and hard to produce with a tan color.

S-the rasberry hits the nose first starting sweet.  Dark chocolate comes in next and is quite strong with notes of caramel underneath.  Hints of toffee and a touch alcohol in the back.

T-the taste is darn good and has some nice flavors that play off of each other.  Rasberry and alcohol hit you first, slightly warm.  Darker malts take over in the back with dark chocolate, caramel and toffee.  More rasberry sweetness and slightly tart at the finish.

M-the body is quite full, very smooth and slightly creamy.  This is soft and chewy.  The carbonation is a little low but the finish still has a slight crispness.

D-this is extremely tasty and has some great complexity to it.  The rich dark maltiness acompanied by the sweet fruitiness and light tartness play together extremely well.

pours Brick Red Murky brown with almost no head. the carbonation sticks around and keeps a thin lacing around the edge of the glass.

Smells like musty raspberrys with cocoa powder. Im not getting much else out of the aroma. I was expecting alcohol at least with 13.50% but not even a nose of that

tastes like a powerful malty doppelbock with heavy milk chocolate with tons of tart raspberry flavors. there is some caramel in here and a little of that musty flavor that I get in the smell.

the beer is slightly syrupy but has just enough carbonation to make it so it isnt suited for putting on pancakes.

the heavy flavors, thickness, and musty tarness make this a sipper. not an easy drinker in that respect. but so damn tasty I can keep sipping on this.

This is much like a desert wine or port in the way it drinks so I would drink it alone after dinner. maybe, just maybe I could have this alongside a plain piece of vanilla bean cheesecake. might need a cup of coffee to wash em both down :)

Was able to snag a 2007 vintage of this, actually 2, the other one will cellar for a bit longer.

It pours into my snifter like syrup and it is a brownish/reddish/goldish color with a surprising head after the higher gravity pour.

The smell is pretty outrageous, it is thick with caramel, chocolate, vanilla, and most dominant, raspberry. It smells like liquid dessert. 

The mouthfeel is full-bodied as expected but not as good as Aventinus Eisbock, which remains the king of all Eisbocks, but it is semi-syrupy and lightly carbonated.

The flavor follows the nose, with Raspberry liquer, hints of caramel, brandy, and other dark fruits. It isnt the taste explosion I was expecting after smelling it, but it is good nonetheless. The alcohol is surprisingly well hidden and there really isnt enough here (although I split a bottle, but still) to really get your throat burning.

This is probably my second favorite Eisbock, I cant wait for my next bottle.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-03-2010 15:38:21

Poured into a flute. Big thanks to OHLRangers for this treat. 2007 vintage.

3.5 A: Opaque deep reddish purple color. No head, but signs of carbonation exist. A bit of particulate junk falls to the bottom.

4.5 S: Strong raspberry as in a reduced raspberry puree. Almost like some sort of liquour, but without the super high alcohol. Surprisingly chocolatey as well. I guess maybe like a highly fruited raspberry chocolate cake. Really nice.

3.5 T: Taste isnt nearly as good as the nose. Tartness from the raspberry is there, but there isnt a ton of raspberry taste (unlike NG RT). Still pretty chocolatety, but not really that sweet, which is disappointing. I was hoping for something really sweet and fruity. A bit too much roasty bitterness as well. Alcohol is well hidden like in most Kuhnhenn brews. While this isnt bad, it doesnt live up to expectations.

3.5 M: Only a thickish medium body. I was hoping for more. Just a touch of carbonation, this would be better with more. Not as creamy of smooth as Id like either.

3.5 D: Again, this isnt bad, but I was hoping for something really sweet and fruity, like a port or something. The way it is (this vintage anyway) isnt the way I would have envisioned a beer of this nature coming out. Id love the try the 2004, but I doubt I ever will.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2010 01:03:23

Big thanks owed to Normyk for this long time want. What a special little beer to just give away, essentially.

Split with Ryan011235. Poured into two taster mini snifters.

A- This little bottle is quite the spectacle. Little mini 6.3 fl oz clear bottle, dipped in a burgundy wax that matches the beer inside. The tiny presentation is an interesting contradiction to the huge beer thats inside. The bottle looked like it was going to turn out flat, but thankfully I am presented with a very small head. It fades down to a collar before disappearing completely. The thick, concentrated beer leaves a solid coating on the side of the glass. The color is a lovely, deep sanguine red.

S- This aroma is in your face raspberry puree. Its very juicy and fresh. It calls forth images of raspberry preserves or a slice of raspberry pie. Although raspberries are the main characteristic here, it is possible to pick out a slight notion of the malts below. I can pick out a slight bit of rich chocolate. This is undoubtedly the most raspberry-strong aroma out there.

T- As expected, raspberry preserves are right in your face. It starts sweet and juicy but moves into a more leafy, wild raspberry flavor. There is a suggestion of tartness with a some bitterness at the finish. A little bit of rich chocolate is blended with the raspberries. Naturally, alcohol doesnt let itself be forgotten but it doesnt crash the party either. Its big and spicy but not bigger than those delicious raspberries.

M- Carbonation starts out kinda prickly. It does die down, especially with all the swirling Ive been doing. Once the carbonation has subsided a bit the sheer thickness of this beer can be fully appreciated. Its very syrupy and chewy. The juicy raspberries cling to every surface of the palate.

D- Nursing my little pour is a test. I would have easily been able to drink more than this whole bottle.

2007 Bottling 6.7oz sampled12/15/2008

Pours a slightly cloudy dark purple with a minimal head that disappears almost instantly. The nose is very fruity as would be expected, lots of raspberrys, dark caramelized malts, alcohol. Smell is very sweet almost like raspberry liqueur. Taste is fruity, malty with an alcohol bit that lingers on in the finish. Very tasty, like a port but sweeter. This one is definitely a sipper. The body is thick, the mouthfeel is sticky, carbonation is low. Great sipping beer or nightcap. I need to try more from this brewery!

This beer is a megaton bomb of flavors.  The nose is loaded with caramel, hints of alcohol, and the slightest whiff of raspberry.  If you smelled it without knowing what was there, you would not think it was a beer, and you wouldnt notice the raspberries; you might confuse it for some kind of delicious caramel cheesecake.  But then you take a sip and theres a huge rush of raspberry goodness, lightly tart to offset the huge sweet flavors of caramel, vanilla, semisweet chocolates, and toffees.  Its pretty much desert in a glass, and I prefer it to the few ice wines Ive tried.

6.3 oz bottle courtesy of deyholla poured into my CCB Snifter. 2007 Vintage. Thanks! After a hard day of shoveling and chores for my Snow Day, its time to settle in. Pours a rusty reddish brown hue, good haze, darker, with a small frothy tannish head that dies to a tiny ring, laces small. Light bubbles creep up from the bottom. Aromas are deep rich luscious raspberries, caramel and toffee malt sweetness back this beast, with pit fruit, preserves, touches of deep bakers chocolate really put this into a more complex level. Touches of vanilla. Initial is heavier end of medium bodied, offering rich raspberry skins, fruit, sweet and touches of tart mingle with rich toffee, caramel, biscuit sweet malts. Touches of cocoa creep in, semi-sweet bitterness, moving  back into a coffee cake subtle sweetness, dessert with raspberries, tart and sweet, the bakers chocolate really gives it a bitter kick, there is nothing cloying about this beer and I could definitely see it complimenting a dessert quite well. Lingering raspberry tannins, juicy fruit with bigger caramel and toffee malts, and that touch of chocolate on the backend really puts this above and beyond for me. Touches of vanilla, sweetness, the alcohol remains really well hidden and wins an extra point for me because of it. So much more than  a "fruit beer". Cheers.

2007 bottle from goryshkewych.  13.8% abv, 6.3 oz.  Poured into a champagne flute glass.  Murky crimson color with just an ultra light head on top.  No retention.  The first whiff shows caramel and molasses with an aroma of raspberry and milk chocolate following.  Rich, assertive, and creamy flavors.  Lots of caramel.  Like those Werthers Originals.  Theres also a lot of the fruit here from the raspberry but also plum and tart cherry skin.  A touch of chocolate rounds out the flavors.  Its a bit boozy but in a soothing and warming way.  Only slight oxidation so Id say the bottle has held up well.  This is probably not something Id want to drink a lot of in a seating, and Im not compelled to go out of my way to try and get another bottle, but it was the perfect after dinner/dessert drink to cap off a good day.

07 bottle courtesy Sean - much appreciated!  Pours a murky brown/red with a slight ring of tan foam hugging the edges of the glass.  Bit of a glass swirl produces a nice glacial ebb of carbonation.  Aroma is raspberry syrup, soft chocolate, caramel, and light raisin/date notes.  Wow.  Thick and sweet raspberry in the taste followed by slightly oxidized caramel and chocolates notes with a minor sour twang on the finish.  Creamy and smooth feel in the mouth.  Excellent sipping beer that I suspect may have been a touch better a few years ago.

Bottle.  No carbonation or head.  Red colour.  Aroma of hard candy with a funky sourness and fresh raspberry fruit.  Full bodied, syrupy mouthfeel.  Flavour of raspberry with a background sour funkiness, some cough syrup.  Pairs nicely with dessert.

2007 bottle brought back from Michigan. Feel like this bottle may have been a little past its prime, but still tasty.  Aroma and flavor of raspberry, dark chocolates, definite vinous quality to this one, finish is more dry than expected. Not as tart as expected, flavor a little muddled (possibly due to age of bottle).  Would like to try a newer bottle to compare.

A-Body is a very hazy red/brown hue-pours with absolutely no head- but fogginess is thick and dynamic.

S-Rich red raspberries, dark chocolate, caramel, and some boozy undertones. The raspberries really mix with the chocolate bock tones well.

T- Mild to moderate sour raspberries, creamy, cocoa upfront. Cocoa comes through more for the finish as an alcohol burn intensifies. A moderate sting of alcohol and a hint of cocoa come through for the finish-what lingers is a hint of raspberry and a big alcohol warmth.

M-Mild to moderate carbonation and fairly smooth light body with very little alcohol consistency.

D- For a nontraditional example of a hard to find style that it crammed with alcohol-this is really really good-happy to finally have the opportunity to enjoy this one!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-28-2010 02:52:02

#2300. Bottle with huge thanks to pailhead! You are awesome bro! 2007 Vintage. Cloudy reddish color with a small amount of carbonation. Aroma is a small bit of raspberry cough syrup, sweet fruit and light sugar. Flavor is tart with a fat raspberry flavor. Heavy wood aged with a tartness that lingers on forever. A bit dry on the finish. Great!

Bottle from Cavies Secret Santa, Pailhead.  2007 bottle.  Pour is a completely opaque purple-brown with no head.  Aroma is very tart, raspberry, sweet, alcohol, and chocolate.  Taste is incredibly tart, very fruity raspberry, definite alcohol, and a surprisingly sweet finish, and what tastes like a razzle something smoothie from Jamba Juice.  Finish is hot and beautiful.

2007 vintage. bottle thanks to spudclampdawg. Pours thick with a deep garnet hue and barely donating any head to speak of. Nose is cherries, oak barrel, red wines, rasberries, chocolate caramel, cherry pie and sweet candy like malts. The taste starts with huge cherry and rasberry tartness and mixes with sweet malts and chocolate, but is largely dominated by rasberries, tartness, cherries, and fresh fruit sweetness. Mouthfeel is smooth. flavor lingers. The aroma wears a thick mask to what lies in the taste.  So glad to try it.

Shared with bmanning at a tasting in November 2009.

187mL bottle poured in champagne flutes.

A: Pours a dark ruby with a tiny tan head that shines brightly in the flute.

S: Lots of raspberries--nay, raspberry tootsie rolls--sit atop a sweet malt base with a little bit of extra chocolate, and hits of earthiness.

T: Again, this really reminded me of a raspberry tootsie roll filled with a bit of alcohol. The flavors underneath were quite nice, with slight hints of brown sugar/molasses, a bit of maple, and maybe some anise.

M: Medium body with only a bit of carbonation.

D: Very rich in flavor, but without the perfect balance, this one was great to try and sip for a while, but didnt live up to the hype for me. A very interesting brew that is well worth trying, I wasnt completely sad to see my glass completely emptied.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-21-2009

6.3 oz bottle labeled 2007. Deep caramel brown body with very thin tan bubbles that dont quite come to a "head". Intense tart raspberry hard candy aroma with caramel and milk chocolate, faint hint of citrus hops. Flavors of  raspberry concentrate, lactose, root beer, toasty malts, and a touch of sourness. Creamy on the tongue with a sour, unsweetened dark chocolate finish.

Vintage 2007, tasted from a 6.3oz bottle. Pours a hazy light red wine color with only a tiny fizzy huntnod a head that quickly disappears. The nose is super sweet with melted caramel aroma, chocolate covered raspberries, and some light vanilla. For a fruit beer, this really maintains a very malty aroma with the raspberry taking a back seat. The flavor is just as surprising because of its dryness. There is raspberry sweetness up front, but the caramel malt and vanilla flavors are very dry. The body is medium at most with a sticky texture, light carbonation and a raspberry and caramel finish that lasts forever. Although the alcohol is very high, I wish this beer was bigger so I could drink more.

Bottle. Pours a murky opaque mahogany color with very little head. What head there is is a slight tan color that collars aromd the glass. The aroma is pretty unassuming with notes of raspberry and malt. Medium/heavy mouthfeel with slight carbonation. Raspberry undertones carry throughout the beer wih other notes of vanilla and caramel. A sipper for sure. Slight alcohol showing. Not the most appetizing looking but a tasty beer for sure.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2013 2007 vintage.  Poured a murky, but mud brown.  Big raspberry nose.  A confusing taste with raspberry, cognac, chocolate, and toffee. flavors.  Some oxidation, with tons of sediment.  Not really my thing...
Re-rate:  my original rating of 3.2 was way off.  Dark guardian was kind enough to share the new release.  Tons of raspberry notes with milk chocolate undertones.  Just fantastic....

Bottle courtesy of Boutip! Cheers!
2007 Vintage. Dark red/brown with no cap. Moves like a liquor in the glass on a slow turn. Stellar aroma.. Sweet and sour raspberries just as I like em. Chocolate... this whole thing reminds me of Lindt Raspberry filled chocolates (the best!). Toffee, cognac, cherries, awesome! The aroma never leaves even after extensive sitting. The taste is pretty fine even if Im noting some oxidization... I think. Some alcohol, very sweet caramel with dull chocolate in the middle and then theres all this sourness. Wonderful! Raspberry is everywhere and peers out very clean in tiny waves. Some medicinal qualities here. Oily mouth feel, thick bodied, leaves sourness behind. Excellent brew.

2007 vintage.

Aroma:Sweet Raspberry, and chocolate, a little slightly oxidized malt. A little boozy.

Appearance:Deep reddish brown. Very little head. Very good lacing.

Taste:Tons and tons of raspberry flavor on the foretaste. Caramel, chocolate, sweet malt flavors. Fruit punch on the aftertaste.

Palate:Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. A little alcohol heat.

Overall:This makes a fantastic after-dinner beer. Amazingly drinkable, very sweet, great fruity flavors, and ages really well.

2007 bottle shared with my lovely wife on my 32nd birthday.  She really is everything to me.  Small hiss upon opening, looks flat in the glass, though carbonation is detected.  Dark toffee colored, little nicotine yellow on the edges.  Jammy fresh raspberry aroma, some young oak, more juice.  Drinks as a cordial, sweet from the fruit, envelopes into dark chocolate and brandy followed by dry toasted oak.

2007 Bottle shared by SoLan. Pours dark ruby color with no head. Nose is raspberries, chocolate, molaasses, candied sugar, and almost cheescake like aromas. Flavor is the same as the nose with the raspberries prominent. Sweet, caramel, get the chocolate as well, slight roasty characteristics, with a hint of bitterness in there as well. There is so much going on in this beer and loves every sip of it. Great Beer!!!

6.3oz bottle "07 Vintage (Courtesy of hopscotch)-58° in Flute-Pours a dark amber with no head and an aroma of raspberry and malt. Taste of raspberry, alcohol, malt, chocolate, and caramel. This full bodied brew is rather interesting and is a nice tasting cordial for after dinner.  Quite yummy and hides the ABV fairly well.

2007 Nip bottle courtesy of bulldogp04.  thanks man!  Brought this to the DC epic tasting and CaptainCougar brought out a 2004 bottle of this and another 2007 bottle.  After tasting all three sufficiently, I can honestly say that I dislike this beer.  04 bottle was pretty oxidized.  Aroma of raspberry, booze, bread, earth.  Taste was oxidized raspberry jam with heavy booze.  Only thing I would use this for is a syrup on a waffle with fresh raspberries and whip cream.  Too hot, weird raspberry syrup flavor.  Bleh

Bottle. 2004 vintage. Pours a dark reddish amber color with no head. Has a sweetish malty strong raspberry aroma. Sweetish malty slightly tart raspberry flavor. Has a sweetish malty earthy raspberry finish. Long aftertaste of raspberries.

2007 vintage bottle from a very generous secret Santa (msante79). Pours plum. Nose is raspberry, plum, aged oak and chocolate. Taste is aged chocolate, raspberry, aged wine and light woods. Amazing brew!

2007 nip from someone I cant remember - thanks, whoever you are! Darkish pour, like that unique blended fruit color one encounters in smoothies, pulped fruit of a lavenderish hue. Wicked fresh berry nose is extremely inviting, revealing no hint of overdone booze and just a hint of the sweet concoction. Nice thick mouthfeel, faintly oily perhaps but in a way that seems to suit the brew well. Sweet and sour fruits dominate the flavor, with the chocolate profile emerging as a dry and dusky complement to the tart fruits, with an earthy finish. Not nearly as sweet as Id expected, and very good indeed.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2007 Vintage. Split with my fiancee with an iced chocolate brownie each.

A: Murky, brackish red-brown... the pour into the first glass has a minuscule fizzy head that quickly died, the second glass had nothing. No lacing.

S: Bright tart raspberries, chocolate, caramel and sweet sugars. Dessert wine-like. Incredibly inviting with layers of all things sweet and desserty.

T: Muted raspberries, chocolate and caramel abound. Surprisingly sour. Very rich, too rich in fact even for the pairing with the chocolate brownie. A bit too concentrated flavor and booze-wise.

M: Smooth, slick, slightly acidic, with a slight alcohol burn in the finish. Port-like in weight and feel.

O: This is an interesting beer, and one I am glad I tried... its a bit too profound for me. If it showed a bit more restraint it would move up in my book.
Bottle..dark red brown pour with no head..Aroma is caramel, chocolate and raspberries...flavor of chocolate and raspberries. Tart..thick.

6.3 fl. oz. bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a Scotch Irish taster glass. 
App.:  Very deep, hazy mahogany with a tan rim.
  
Aroma:  Really deep raspberry jam, some fresher raspberries, raspberry greens, alcohol, molasses and brown sugar, a little brightness, thick, heavy and sweet.
  
Palate:  Full bodied, very limited effervescence, quite syrupy, stings a little.
  
Flav.:  Lots of raspberry notes  jammy, fresh, green, caramelized, alcohol, big deep malts; sweet with a good deal of tang and bitterness and a quite alcoholic finish with some maltiness and raspberry notes.

A sipper for sure.  Too much alcohol for my tastes.

Bottle, thanks tarheels! Pours ruby with a big dark head. Nose is big on raspberries and chocolate. Flavor is raspberries with chocolate. Reminds me of eating chocolate covered raspberries but in beer form. Definitely a desert beer.
Vintage 2007. Thnx Glouglouburp! Dark mahony, brown colored brew. Tart in the aroma, marzipan. Flavor has raspberries, some pleasant sourness, tart and marzipan. Smooth texture.

2007 bottle, pours a hazy, sticky plum red with a ring of beige head and thick lacing.  Nose is rich raspberry pulp, heavy malt, caramel, maybe a bit of white chocolate.  Tart and very bitter, boozy in the mouth.  Kind of acrid bitterness that just lingers.  Some heavy malt underneath.  Tough to get into the subtleties of this with that huge boozy bitterness.  Could be an infected bottle.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this little 187 ml bottle. 

2007 vintage. The beer pours a hazy brown color with a few bubbles but not real head. The aroma is a mix of brown sugar, chocolate, caramel, maple, alcohol and a little bit of raspberry. The flavor is different, with a ton of fruit and chocolate. This beer tastes like chocolate dipped raspberries. There is also some alcohol in the flavor. The beer is very sweet. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation. Wow, what a beer. So glad I got to try it.

Pour is a deep red, burnt amber.  aroma is intrusive raspberry with some orange zest, chambord, chocolate and some light booziness.  Flavor is intensely raspberry fruit with some hazelnut, booze, raspberry cheesecake, excellent desert, remeniscient of a desert wine or an ice wine.  damn good, sipper

Big thanks to oteyj. Plum colored pour with absolutely no head. Aroma is amazing; tons of chocolate, raspberry, cheesecake, brandy, almond paste, Chambord, and some orange rind. Flavor is so huge and delicious. Tons of raspberry jam, hazelnut, vanilla, and cheesecake once again. So sweet, but so delicious and complex. Palate is sticky and syrupy sweet, but glides down wayyy too easily for such a small bottle. An absolute treat.

Garnet pour with zero head. Thanks to craftycarl. The nose is loaded with chocolate and huge raspberry notes, giving way to cheesecake, orangepeel, and Chambord. The flavor is absolutely bursting with fresh raspberries, hazelnut, booze, and milk chocolate. The palate is thick, rich, and ultra soft and smooth. The finish is slippery sweet and impeccably delicious.

Sampled at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  2004 vintage.  Pours a translucent, chocolate brown with zero head.  Aroma is raspberry, chocolate, burnt sugar, dark breads, some oxidation.  Flavor is big on berries, chocolate, bread dough, a little sherry, jam on whole grain bread.  Spencer remarked, "this would taste great over a waffle."  Full bodied, sticky finish and a touch hot.

Bottles at DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010, courtesy of Spencer - thank you sir!  
2004 - Murky brown, no head, no lacing.  Aroma of chocolate liquer.  Taste of chocolate-covered brandied cherries, vanilla.  Tasty.
2007 - more chocolate in the nose, higher carbonation.  Not bad.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2014 > Beautiful baked cherry aroma is met sadly with an over the hill, lifeless body
[ Bottle ][ CaptainCougar ][ 180ml ][ Gift ][ Prairie Teku ][ 5/8/14 ]
>> 2004 Nip. This was a gift from a couple years ago from Tom to celebrate my engagement to biggirlpanties. Finally cracked this open for a special occasion, buying our first home together! Cap came off with no hiss, pour is flat. Color is deep brune, tea highlights. Nose is really awesome- baked black cherry, milk chocolate, baked raspberry souffle, soy, sherry. Taste is over the hill with water, paper, mild cranberry acid. Palate is thin, tart, mild paper. It is okay to drink, but much better to just smell. Fun to try, but over the hill. Thank you Tom for this generous gift :)
>!< paper, oxidized, lemon, water


Earlier Ratings: Miniature bottles courtesy of my boys SpencerDB, CaptainCougar, anyone else? So we tried 2004 and 2007. The pour is murky, muddy brown with low carbonation. Let me just say that this was not impressive whatsoever. Okay- its a slightly raspberry tangy super malt forward barleywine. I mean that is what this is. There is a lot of milk chocolate, raspberry chocolate, and it is just full of toffee. I mean its good but nothing that blew me out of the water. And that was the 04. The 07 literally tasted like broccoli. So- this is one that Ill have to revisit. For now- meh. 7/4/6/3/12=3.2Re-Rate:Another 2007 bottle. Pours muddy, reddish brown and completely flat. Excellent aroma that is full of toffee, creme brulee, caramel, chocolate covered strawberries. Taste is tart, light, more raspberry character than I remember. Still thin bodied. 9/4/7/3/13=3.6

2007 6.3oz Bottle received in an in person trade with iceicebaby at the Bullfrog Brewery release party for Frambozen. $12.99 sticker on it. Sean you are an awesome Beer Advocate!

Appearance: Murky brown with red corners. Minimal head, retention, or lacing.

Smell: Loads of raspberry, chocolate, and some liquor type presence. Very nice when it opens up.

Taste: Wow this is a total chocolate covered fruit / booze dessert type beer. It is absolutely unique, refined, and delicious!

mouthfeel: Thick but a medium body! Amazing!

Drinkability: Extremely drinkable for 13.50% abv

This was an amazing experience...

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-13-2009

Ohh my goodness. Nose is incredible.... like raspberry cheesecake. pour is nice redish color with nice foam. flavor is similar to the nose with more alcohol and some malt but damn is this an interesting dessert beer. you could make anyone like beer with this one

Opened this gem in celebration of a new job in Pacific Beach! Pours a murky dark brown/maroon color with clear orange edges and little carbonation from the 2007 bottle acquired from a trade with Doodler (thanks, Scott!):  A tantalizing nose of milk chocolate, raspberry puree, chocolate covered strawberries, caramel, warm fudge brownie, and vanilla. Soft carbonation just quietly pricks the tongue. Medium-bodied. Creamy and slick simultaneously. A strong blend of raspberries and sour malt take the flavor for a turn towards tart, but sweet chocolate and caramel notes allures it back to earth. Drinkability: Think of traditional oysters, strawberries and champagne remixed into this unsurpassed brew. Its seductive and vampish. Pairing: Chocolate cake, cheesecake, apple strudel, or anything sexy. Rebuy: Yeah. #456 on 17052010, DG.
7oz bottle fro who knows who. Dark orange pour with very little head. Light raspberry aroma. Sweet raspberry flavor, very mild and very well done. (1248)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 6.3 oz. bottle from shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a hazy reddish-brown with some carbonation and sediment and a tiny head.  Aroma of caramel, funky raspberries, vanilla, chocolate, and wood.  Flavor of raspberries, chocolate, caramel, alcohol, vanilla, wood, yeast, and acidic notes.  Maybe some oxidization.  Boozier than expected.  Sweet, tart, and a little acidic.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a woody mouthfeel.  Really interesting, and I would have been interested to try this really fresh to see how the raspberry character in particular has changed over the years.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2011 Bottle. 2007 vintage.
Appearance : Hazy dark cherry-colored.

Aroma : Rich cherries with light chocolatr and vanilla. Notes of wax.

Taste : Big cherries and light alcohol. Some vanilla and wax. Light bitterness on finish with some alcohol.

Overall : Very intense. We were only 4 on the small bottle and I had a hard time to drink my share. Very tasty and all but a bit too intense and too rich. I dont think this is better balanced than the Belgian Red anymore.

2004 bottle shared by MartinT 
Appearance : Red with a tiny head. 

Aroma : Raspberries, lots of vanilla. Quite sweet. A bit dusty. Notes of almonds and wax.

Taste : Raspberries, lots of vanilla and some chocolate. 

Overall : Textures is very special. Very smooth. The vanilla feels pretty intense. The notes of chocolate are also really nice. Felt quite balanced overall which was quite surprising. It felt a lot more balanced than the NG Belgian Red for example. This is a real threat that I need to have again ! Thanks Martin !! 100512 8,3,9,4,17;4.1

I forgot who sent me this in a trade, but thank you! This was a real treat. It pours a murky brown with no head. The aroma is chocolate, raspberries, wood, earth, and caramel in that order. Oh man, this is going to be rich. The flavor is surprisingly tart with lots of sweet raspberries, nuts, wood, and chocolate. Very tart all the way through with a woody finish. The flavors are all well integrated and nothing is overpowering. This is a super rich, tasty treat, and the nip was a perfect sample size for one person.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013 The aroma of delicious sweet raspberries and malts blend very well. The appearance is flat dark maroon red amber with very little head. The flavor is tart and bland malts with notes of raspberries, but not sweet like in the aroma. The booziness manages to stay somewhat smooth throughout, but still does the job.

2007 bottle pours murky dark brown with a very thin off white head.  Aroma is dusty wood, raspberry, some strawberry and booze.  Sweet caramel malt notes with some moldy funky wood flavors and soft fresh raspberry in the finish.  A nice sipper.

2007 Bottle: Mahogany colored with just a thin white ring, no real head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, dark fruits and raspberries. Faint hints of coffee, tart raspberries, oily on the palate and light hints of oxidation. Some raisin like flavors, accompanied by light notes of chocolate and licorice. Finish has a slight alcoholic warmth. Not sure if it was the age or storage conditions, but this really didnt live up to the expectations I had for it. There are some good flavors going on, but it doesnt really all come together for me... definitely not worth the hefty price tag I paid for it.

tap at Hop Devil Grill. Sweet, raspberry fruity syrup. Cloying and sticky caramel and boozy. Maply, vanilla, almond, butter and whipped cream. Some boozy notes. Sort of reminds me of the raspberry syrup at ihop (but better quality obviously). Interesting, unique beer. Not sure it was worth $10 for 8 oz however.

On tap at Hop Devil. Pours a deep maroon with creamy beige head. Awesome intense aroma of fresh raspberries, raspberry jam, and rich chocolate syrup. The balance of sweet chocolate and tart raspberry in the nose is really phenomenal. Flavor is a similarly awesome balance of tart raspberry with sweet chocolate syrup, with the addition of vanilla and chocolate liqueur quality. All the notes are of really high quality Lusciously creamy mouthfeel with a slightly stinging liqueur finish. I think I have a bit of a crush on this beer.

2007 Bottle.  Dense dark brown/slightly reddish pour, little carbonation and a rich aroma of raspberry syrup.  Flavor is creamy raspberry, caramel, silky and pleasantly a little boozy on the finish.  A good beer, but a bit overhyped and overpriced in my opinion.  Definitely worth a try, but I would probably never purchase (or trade for) it again.
Bottle at Malteprovning. Sweet intense Raspberry Fudge Vanilla. Very sweet taste of caramell fudge raspberry and strawberry.

Once more thanks to trevor211 for sharing at the epic beer weekend while I was in the States. Pours surprisingly brown with minimal tan head. Hazy, cider appearance. Nose is thick, sweet dense dark fruit. Raspberry syrup, fudge, raisins. Body is smooth for abv, which is well hidden, almost wish there were more eis here. Beyond the raspberry fruit layer the body is a big undefined/unrefined, with lots of slightly sour malts. Raspberry candy, sucker, fruit roll-up, a bit tart. Milk chocolate and apple cider. Bitter-tart nose and finish. Surprising and unique, but didnt really love it.

2007 187mL bottle, thanks to ryan.  Pours a very cloudy reddish brown.  The aroma definitely lives up to the description of "a dessert treat", smells like sweet and tart raspberries with some alcohol.  Tastes like delicious raspberries, with raisins, chocolate and alcohol.  Nice slightly bitter raspberry peel finish.
Brown pour with a slight read tint.  Lots of pure raspberries on the aroma and flavor.  Caramel and chocolate notes.  Dry with a bitter finish.

Rating #1200. 2007 vintage. Bottle from a trade with Boutip. Pours cloudy brownish color with light tan head. Aromas of raspberries and chocolate. It tastes like a port wine with lots of raspberries and chocolate. Some oxidation. Medium body with moderate carbonation. A very nice after dinner drink. Thanks Phil.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TylvUGJIi_

HUGE thanks to StFun for this one!  Wow! There are a million things going on here! Amazing real sweet and sour raspberry going on with sweet malts, pie spices, crisp crust, and more. Amazing!  Wonderful!!!

Green nip bottle 2007 vintage poured a hazy red with a lingering ring of pink foam. Aromas of raspberry, cookie, carmel and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, raspberrytoffee and spice with a smooth lingering raspberry finish.
pours brown/red.  very raspberry aroma.  very tart taste, really tangy.  great feel an goes down pretty smooth.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with plenty of red highlights to it. The beer has a very low amount of visible carbonation and almost no head.

S: Great notes of rich chocolate and raspberries fill the nose with some mild alcohol and vanilla aromas coming in on the finish.

T: The raspberries give a wonderfully sweet and tart flavor combination that works nicely with the chocolate (oxidation?) flavors of the beer. The mild tartness of the fruit gives a nice balance to an otherwise sweet beer.

M: Although the beer appears to be quite flat, there are some small, tingly carbonation bubbles. Their presence is much appreciated as they prevent the beer from turning to syrup.

D: The alcohol is somewhat noticeable in this, but the flavors are rather impressive and bold, so they hold up well to the heat. I will have to open one of my bottles of this soon as I love this beer.

2007 bottle from a while back, trade with miketd, I think. Pours a rich dark rum with virtually no head, though carbonation is there. Nose is raspberry, caramel, a kiss of cocoa and cherry pie. On taste, pretty extraordinary. Full of caramelized malt notes, burnt sugar, raspberry syrup and caramel. light cocoa and alcohol shoot through as well. Warming and nice. Very good and very interesting.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2010 6.3oz nip bottle from silphium...thanks Brad! - Pours rosy mahogany with a thin, velvety tan head. Smells of sweet caramel, booze-soaked German chocolate cake, raisins, molasses, coconut--about the only thing Im not getting is raspberry. Not that thats bad, because this is a sweet, decadent treat, but the raspberry just isnt there. Taste is port wine, raspberries, caramel--sweeter than the smell, but not boozy at all. And Im happy the raspberries are finally coming through. A little bitter on the finish--not sure where that comes from, but its not bad. Smooth and syrupy, this coats the glass--really viscous. If this wasnt $10 a bottle, I would drink this for dessert every night.

(6.3oz bottle thanks to BA Shumista 2007 vintage, rating #1000!) Pours deep garnet red with light bubbles and coats the glass well. Nose of raisins, figs, maple syrup, raspberries, rum, and sherry. This is rich and complex. Taste of brandy, bread, raspberries, raisins, figs. The alcohol is very well hidden despite tasting and smelling like other alcohols. The linger is delicious of alcohol soaked raspberries. An excellent beer!

Im rating this on a 1 oz. sample I had at the brewpub.  Cloudy dark gold with a pillowy soft head.  Smells of tart rasberries and candied cinnamon.  Tastes of fermented rasberies, subtle hints of candy sugar, then a warming spicy candy cinnamon.  Some flavors of wheat and honey.  I wish I was rich, because you need to be to buy this.

2007 version on tap at Kuhnhenn. Opaque reddish brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma of raspberry, grainy malt and caramel. Super malty flavor with caramel, a hint of chocolate and lots of raspberry. Lives up the hype, but Wisconsin Belgian Red is still the ruler of fruit beers.

2007 bottle thanks to xnoxhatex! Pours a flat thick syrupy but surprisingly tasty looking syrupy basically clear rust color with no head.  Strong sweet caramel pudding like aroma, some fridge, nice aged raspberry tartness, lightly doughy, quite sweet but well melded.  Wow is that sweet, tastes exactly like a raspberry filled shortbread cookie, wow, thats crazy, but super super sweet, mouth puckeringly sweet, some faint tootsie-roll like chocolate fills it out and the alcohol does a great job of accenting all the rich flavors. Medium bodied, totally flat, viscous but not sticky, warming alcohol in the finish, Devon tells me it had some carbonation at the brewery so Ill go with that.  Very unique beer that Im cant wait to try again.
Vintage 2007.  Pours redish brown with very little carbonation.  Aromas of raspberry, smoke and alcohol.  Flavors of tart raspberry.  Light to medium bodied.  It was OK overall.

187 mL bottle of the 2007 vintage.  Pours deep brown with an off-white ring the only hint of a head (there are those who would mark it down for this, but this beer should be close to still).  Aroma is strong raspberry, smooth chocolate, caramel, cherry, toffee, butterscotch, with just touches of alcohol that give it a very wine-like quality.  I could spend a long time just sniffing at this.  Flavor is of chocolate raspberries, strawberry, cherry, caramel, and toffee, with a little alcohol bite and mild oxidation notes.  Very refined.  Cant say I at all regret the money I spent on this small bottle.

Wax covered nip; 2007 vintage; so after 17 months in procession and the last 8 spent in the fridge waiting to be drunk, I finally cracked a fabled Raspberry Eisbock; slight hiss with a slightly murky, brownish red pour and trace tan head to the edges; aromas of raspberries, a touch of oxidation, chocolate truffles; yummy nose; big, strong body with chocolate upfront mixed with strawberries and raspberries; slight tartness and lots of chocolate cake; wow, a decadent dessert; the slight oxidation definitely detracts a little bit and IMO this is not quite up to snuff with the NG Raspberry Tart; I do like the malty, chocolate traits here as opposed to a pure (and perfect) fruit bomb; sticky sweet and bone dry in the mouth; not much heat but plenty potent; maybe not quite my cup of tea, but not denying the experience with this one; geeking out about beer pushes you to the eventual discovery (and drinking) of beers like this, and in that sense this is right up there in terns of uniqueness and amazement in what beer can be

2007 vintage.

A very cloudy reddish brown color. A minimal pale beige head develops, but dissipates instantly into a fine ring of lacings. After a while even these tiny bubbles fade away. Honestly, the qualities of this beer surly doesnt lie in its appearance.

The smell is very powerful. Huge amounts of sweet malts makes the smell really heavy. Plenty of genuine aromas of raspberries, but the fruits are not as prominent as I had expected. A hint of chocolate, some leather and tobacco, and quite a lot of oak-barrel. Alcoholic fumes hit the noose, but are well integrated with the sophisticated character of the smell. All in all, its quite reminiscent of fine spirits.

The taste is dominated by a dense and heavy malty character with lots of sweetness to it. The raspberries are present in the mouth, but again they are more subtle than I had expected. The raspberry flavors are of a really genuine quality, no raspberry candy in sight. Caramel, notes of tobacco and leather, and quite a lot of oak. I get a hint of chocolate, but its very faint. Perhaps I pick up the slightest hint of coffee. The finish is almost ridiculously long and has a great warming feeling to it due to the alcohol. The raspberries delivers a nice acidity that goes really great with sweetness from the malts and alcohol. All in all, the raspberries get more prominent towards the finish. Some residual notes of oak barrels and raspberry pits in the finish as well.

Very full-bodied with a thick and creamy mouthfeel. It actually has a surprisingly high level of carbonation (which is still rather gentle) which seems to suit the beer nice since it lightens up the otherwise dense feeling and helps to spread all of the wonderful aromas around the mouth.

This is a great beer. Surly one of a kind that delivers an explosion of flavors and a great beer experience. Drinks like fine spirits, but still with that great character you cant get from any other type of beverage.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

2007 bottle shared at, by plovmand thanks you so much! :-)
Pours cloudy brown with a small tan head. 
Nice and intense aroma with lots of raspberries, chocolate, caramel, vanilla and oak. 
The flavour is sweet and very fruity, with notes of alcohol, caramel and vanilla. Nice complex and full bodied. 
Great beer!

Bottle. Murky reddish brown body with a small off white head. Lovely aroma notes of raspberry, chocolate, caramel, vinous, sweet toffee, vanilla and port. Fantastic complex flavour of barley, dark fruit, caramel, chocolate, port, raspberry, warming alcohol and vanilla. Full bodied. Very lovely!

6.3 oz bottle 2004 vintage.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown color with no head.  The aroma, which quickly makes itself known, is chocolate dipped raspberries, caramel, with port characteristics.  The flavor is more of the same: intense chocolate, caramel, raspberries that were picked at the perfect time, vinous.  Full bodied and great for sipping.  This stays on the palate for some time allowing the flavors time to be savored.  This poured into a snifter on a cold winter night is a nice way to relax.

I have had the 04 and 07, and although the 07 is still good, it doesnt quite compare to the 04 which was (is ) truly special.

Rating #594 for this beer.

This is a great little beer. Taste more like a liquor Chocolate, Caramel, Raspberry its all here a great little after dinner desert beer. This would even be great poured over ice cream. A true treat of a beer and worth seeking out even if just for the novelty of it!

Huge thanks to Bobby91w for this tasty treat. Pours browner than I thought it would - a ruddy medium brown, with only a small ring of bubbles around the edge. The aroma is simply delectable - raspberry syrup, tons of caramel... like something you might drizzle over a great cheesecake. The flavor doesnt quite pull through, though - mouthfeel is great, but theres a grassy note that takes away from the pungent raspberry, and the alcohol shines a bit through the rest of the brew. Still great, but probably a bit over-hyped.

2007.  aroma is candy sweet raspberry with jelly quality similar to swedish fish.   boozy note seems to come and go but appears minor even when it reveals. deep, dark maroon with essentially nil carb.  flavor is mouth watering, juicy fruit with raspberry predominant and submissive caramel malt.. cut with brown sugar sweetness that brings interesting carmelization to the mix and nutty, dopplebock like booze that comes and goes as it did in the aroma. amazingly soft on the palate despite its strength, though it makes itself known in a brandy like burn.  so rewarding to have such a complex fruit beer that still displays signs of actual beer, not just a fruit juice bomb.

2007 bottle. pours a deep brown with no head. aroma is bursting with caramel, chocolate, malts, raspberries. drinks very smooth with chocolate and caramel up front and a nice malt sweetness. raspberries come as you swallow and through the after taste. alcohol isnt really noticable while drinking. fantastic brew and i want more!

2004 Vintage.  Thank you, Peter.  Pours out a flat and very viscous opaque garnet-tinged mahogany brown that throws off a lot of sediment.  The raspberry aroma is still fresh and vibrant and is intermingled with caramel, dark chocolate, soft banana, and subtle spice.  The flavor follows through from this with more raspberry and cocoa and caramel fermentation notes.  The body is well structured with the alcohol definitely in check which offers a lot of substance.  It would benefit from a bit a carbonation to add another level of dimension to the palate. This was a great treat.

2004 bottle with a huge thanks to captaincougar!  consumed christmas morning 2009.  Pours a dark, murky brown with a tiny light tan head.  leaves a ring of small bubbles around the perimeter of the glass.  Aroma opens up with some chocolate covered cherries, toffee, bread pudding, and cocoa dust.  really quite nice.  flavor is a semi tart cherry, basement, caramel, grape mixture with a little booze thrown in for extra character.  Mouthfeel is super silky smooth and slightly sticky.  superb!  This is quite the unique beer.  An extremely tasty, drinkable, and satisfying, beer, red wine, spirit mixture.  awesome.  Very well put together-  exceded expectations.  Thanks again Tom!

On tap during 09 Winter Solstice. 07 Version. Poured a murky burnt umber with minimal head. Aroma was very strong, with sweet raspberries, caramel with a surprisingly small amount of alcohol. There was a slight undertone of honey on the nose. The alcohol was much more present on the tongue, but it meshed well with the raspberry and caramel flavors. The aftertaste left a honey note on your tongue. Surprisingly smooth on the tongue as well.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2012 Been holding on to this one for a while.. Opened it to mark my new job offer. 2007 bottle. Nose of cocoa, sweet malt and raspberry filled the room after opening.
